title: Disappearing Objects: Genealogies of Performance
description:
Perhaps we have entered yet another crisis of representation, one with its own distinct historical stakes. What pressures does this place on us as makers of objects, writing, encounters? How does our work orient itself to these questions? Disappearing Objects takes up these questions through multiple logics—of the aesthetic, of the phenomenological, of the psychoanalytic—to consider how trajectories of form and narrative intersect in the thinking and making of performance. We begin by tracing the convergence of performance, dance and sound in visual art, taking up Foucault’s concept of genealogy to address historical precedent in light of contemporary practice where Hugo Ball’s provocations resonate against the recent works of Ivo Dimchev or Cecilia Bengolea or Pussy Riot. In what ways do such performances respond to and resist their particular historical, cultural, and political contexts? How do these strategies propose a different politics through their ephemerality and resistance to archiving? How does disappearance as a mode of performance challenge forces of commodification? How does the shift from object to performance complicate ideas of temporality and duration? Each seminar will be designed as a workshop including experiments in physical performance practice, conversation, and writing. Expanding our repertoire of performance and writing techniques, we will work with improvisation, somatic and movement-based practices diffracted through texts by Fred Moten, Meg Stuart, Judith Butler, Michel Foucault, Catherine Malabou, Renee Gladman, Denise Ferrara da Silva, Sigmund Freud, H.D., Ligia Clark, Anne Boyer, Maggie Nelson, Dahn Vo, La Ribot, among others, to engage possibilities for critical making and thinking.

Permission of the instructor required.
